text: THE CENTRE FOR
label: H4

text: HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: H4

text: P E E R  R E V I E W  F R A M E W O R K  F O R
label: H4

text: PREDICTIVE ANALYTICS IN
label: HH1

text: HUMANITARIAN RESPONSE
label: HH1

text: MAY 2021
label: BODY

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data centre.humdata.org  |  Join our mailing list: bit.ly/humdatamailing   |  Twitter: @humdata  |  Email: centrehumdata@un.org
label: BODY

text: Humanitarian decision-makers have called for the increased use of predictive analytics to anticipate and better
label: BODY

text: respond to humanitarian crises. However, translating the outputs of predictive models into timely and
label: BODY

text: appropriate responses remains a challenge for several reasons:
label: BODY

text: •	 First, there is no common standard for documenting predictive models and their intended use.
label: BODY

text: •	 Second, there is no common standard or mechanism for assessing the technical rigor and operational
label: BODY

text: readiness of predictive models.
label: BODY

text: •	 Third, the development of predictive models is often led by technical specialists who may not consider
label: BODY

text: important ethical concerns related to the application of models in humanitarian contexts.
label: BODY

text: Since 2018, the United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) Centre for
label: BODY

text: Humanitarian Data (‘the Centre’) has been working with our partners to understand the state of model
label: BODY

text: development and use in humanitarian operations. We have noted a clear desire for quality assurance of models
label: BODY

text: by partners, with the Centre identified as having a unique role to facilitate a peer review process.
label: BODY

text: The following Peer Review Framework for Predictive Analytics in Humanitarian Response (‘the Framework’) aims
label: BODY

text: to create standards and processes for the use of models in our sector. It is based on research with experts and
label: BODY

text: stakeholders across a range of organizations that design and use predictive models. The Framework also draws
label: BODY

text: on best practices from academia and the private sector. The purpose of applying the Framework is to offer
label: BODY

text: advisory support in the development and implementation of predictive models. The results of the review do
label: BODY

text: not constitute an endorsement on behalf of OCHA or the United Nations.
label: BODY

text: In addition to the work on quality assurance through peer review, the Centre’s predictive analytics workstream
label: BODY

text: validates and develops models for use in humanitarian operations. Learn more about these efforts on the
label: BODY

text: Centre’s website: https://centre.humdata.org/predictive-analytics/.
label: BODY

text: 1. INTRODUCTION
label: HH1

text: There are three main roles in the peer review process: the Client, the Reviewers, and the Moderator. Additional
label: BODY

text: stakeholders (individuals or organisations who could be affected by the use of the model or who may use
label: BODY

text: model outputs to take decisions) may be consulted during the review process.
label: BODY

text: The Centre leads the process and works with experts to complete the peer review. The Client is asked to identify
label: BODY

text: a single focal point for the process, although different colleagues may need to be involved for each step.
label: BODY

text: The roles in the process are:
label: BODY

text: •	 The Client: an organization submitting a model for peer review.
label: BODY

text: •	 The Reviewers:
label: BODY

text: ·· Technical Reviewer: an individual with demonstrated expertise in data science or statistics and their
label: BODY

text: application in the relevant context.
label: BODY

text: ·· Ethical Reviewer: an individual with demonstrated expertise in practical and humanitarian ethics.
label: BODY

text: •	 The Moderator: a member of the Centre’s predictive analytics team designated by the Team Lead on a
label: BODY

text: case-by-case basis. In addition, the Centre’s data responsibility team will support the process as needed.
label: BODY

text: 2. ROLES IN THE PEER REVIEW PROCESS
label: HH1

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data centre.humdata.org  |  Join our mailing list: bit.ly/humdatamailing   |  Twitter: @humdata  |  Email: centrehumdata@un.org
label: BODY

text: 2.1 Reviewer Selection and Reviewer Pool
label: HH1

text: The Centre invites experts to submit an application to become a Reviewer in the technical or ethical domain.
label: BODY

text: A Call for Reviewers will be periodically promoted by the Centre in order to attract and maintain a group of
label: BODY

text: experts to support the peer review process.
label: BODY

text: Once accepted, the Reviewer will become part of a Reviewer Pool managed by the Centre. The Moderator will
label: BODY

text: select Reviewers based on availability and a match of skills for the model in reference. Reviewers will not be
label: BODY

text: assigned to review models submitted by their own organization or in case of any other potential conflict of
label: BODY

text: interest. The Reviewer role is unpaid.
label: BODY

text: Partners interested in submitting a model for peer review are asked to submit a request through this form. The
label: BODY

text: Centre will engage with the Client for an initial meeting and process walkthrough. A Moderator is assigned to
label: BODY

text: the review and agrees with the Client on a timeline for the process. The Moderator provides the Model Card
label: BODY

text: template to the Client for the formal submission of the model.
label: BODY

text: The process consists of six steps:
label: BODY

text: 3. STEPS IN THE PEER REVIEW PROCESS
label: HH1

text: Step 1:
label: BODY

text: Model Submission
label: BODY

text: Step 2:
label: BODY

text: Technical Review
label: BODY

text: The Framework aims to support models that are either fully developed or exploratory. Models that are fully
label: BODY

text: developed and have a defined or intended implementation plan will go through the complete peer review
label: BODY

text: process. In the case of exploratory models, it is not possible to evaluate the ethical concerns as the actions that
label: BODY

text: the model would generate are not yet defined. Review of these models will therefore skip steps 3 and 4.
label: BODY

text: The duration of the review process will depend on the steps that need to be completed and the quality of the
label: BODY

text: submission by the Client. A complete review of a fully developed model should take around eight weeks.
label: BODY

text: Step 3:
label: BODY

text: Implementation Plan
label: BODY

text: Submission
label: BODY

text: Step 4:
label: BODY

text: Ethical Review
label: BODY

text: Step 5:
label: BODY

text: Client Consultation
label: BODY

text: Step 6:
label: BODY

text: Recommendations
label: BODY

text: and Model Report
label: BODY

text: PEER REVIEW PROCESS OVERVIEW
label: HH3

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data centre.humdata.org  |  Join our mailing list: bit.ly/humdatamailing   |  Twitter: @humdata  |  Email: centrehumdata@un.org
label: BODY

text: MODEL SUBMISSION
label: HH1

text: In the first step, the Client submits the model for peer review by completing the Model Card template, with
label: BODY

text: support from the Moderator if needed. The Model Card includes the information required throughout the peer
label: BODY

text: review process, including:
label: BODY

text: •	 The scope and the intended use of the model.
label: BODY

text: •	 The methodology of the model, including the reliability of input datasets, potential biases and the model
label: BODY

text: assumptions.
label: BODY

text: •	 The evaluation process of the model and the reliability of the model output.
label: BODY

text: •	 The operational readiness of the model for humanitarian contexts.
label: BODY

text: Providing this information through the Model Card helps the Centre to standardize documentation, allowing
label: BODY

text: stakeholders to compare candidate models.
label: BODY

text: TECHNICAL REVIEW
label: HH1

text: In the second step, the model undergoes a technical review based on the information in the Model Card.
label: BODY

text: The output of this step is a completed Model Evaluation Matrix which highlights the technical strengths and
label: BODY

text: weaknesses for the model’s application in humanitarian action.
label: BODY

text: The Technical Reviewer will assess strengths and weaknesses across the following sections of the Model Card:
label: BODY

text: •	 Intended Use
label: BODY

text: ·· Clarity in the definition of use-cases.
label: BODY

text: ·· Evaluate the understanding of the model’s boundaries, limitations and constraints.
label: BODY

text: •	 Model Development
label: BODY

text: ·· Quality and representativeness of model’s input datasets.
label: BODY

text: ·· Robustness of model methodology.
label: BODY

text: •	 Model Evaluation
label: BODY

text: ·· Reliability of projections with respect to existing benchmarks.
label: BODY

text: ·· Understanding of model failures.
label: BODY

text: •	 Operational Readiness
label: BODY

text: ·· Usability and timeliness of model.
label: BODY

text: ·· Clarity in the definition of roles and responsibilities.
label: BODY

text: If the model being reviewed is only exploratory and has no intended use defined yet, the Moderator will skip
label: BODY

text: steps 3 and 4 and move to set up the consultation with the Client. For models that are fully developed and with
label: BODY

text: an intended use already defined, the Moderator will continue with step 3 in the process.
label: BODY

text: IMPLEMENTATION PLAN SUBMISSION
label: HH1

text: In the third step, the Moderator supports the Client to develop documentation of the intended use of the
label: BODY

text: model. The output of this step is a completed Implementation Plan that summarizes the concrete actions that
label: BODY

text: the model will trigger or inform and clarifies the roles and responsibilities for implementation of the model in
label: BODY

text: humanitarian action.
label: BODY

text: Step 01
label: BODY

text: Step 02
label: BODY

text: Step 03
label: BODY

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data centre.humdata.org  |  Join our mailing list: bit.ly/humdatamailing   |  Twitter: @humdata  |  Email: centrehumdata@un.org
label: BODY

text: ETHICAL REVIEW
label: HH1

text: In the fourth step, the Ethical Reviewer identifies key issues associated with the model and its intended use,
label: BODY

text: assesses the related ethical concerns of different stakeholders, and offers recommendations for how to address
label: BODY

text: these concerns. The output of this step is a completed Ethical Matrix.1 During this step, the Ethical Reviewer
label: BODY

text: will complete a draft matrix, request further information and feedback from the Client, and consult with the
label: BODY

text: Moderator and colleagues from the Centre’s data responsibility team as needed. A detailed description of the
label: BODY

text: process for completing the Ethical Matrix is provided in Annex A.
label: BODY

text: CLIENT CONSULTATION
label: HH1

text: The Moderator will convene a call with the Client and the Reviewers to present and discuss the initial findings
label: BODY

text: of the review. The Client will have the opportunity to provide feedback and to complement the information
label: BODY

text: provided in the Model Card and the Implementation Plan. The Client may also explain if and how any
label: BODY

text: weaknesses in the model have been addressed. If the Client reports that they have taken actions to improve the
label: BODY

text: model, those measures will be reflected in the final versions of the Model Evaluation Matrix and Ethical Matrix.
label: BODY

text: RECOMMENDATIONS AND MODEL REPORT
label: HH1

text: In the final step, the Reviewers develop recommendations based on their review of the model and the feed-
label: BODY

text: back from the Client. When developing recommendations, the Technical and Ethical Reviewers assess addition-
label: BODY

text: al areas which need further attention to mitigate potential concerns in the implementation of the model.
label: BODY

text: The Moderator produces a Model Report based on the information in the Model Card, Model Evaluation Matrix,
label: BODY

text: Implementation Plan, the Ethical Matrix, the Client consultation and the Reviewers’ recommendations. The
label: BODY

text: Moderator will share the Model Report with the Client. The Client may decide whether the Model Report should
label: BODY

text: be made publicly available to stakeholders, on request or be kept confidential. An abstract of the model will be
label: BODY

text: included in the Centre’s Catalogue of Predictive Models.
label: BODY

text: 1    The Ethical Matrix has been adapted from the approach developed by Cathy O’Neil. For more information, see O’Neil, C. Weapons of Math Destruction: How Big
label: BODY

text: Data Increases Inequality and Threatens Democracy. Crown Publishing Group New York, NY, USA, 2016.
label: BODY

text: FEEDBACK
label: BODY

text: The Centre invites individuals and organizations working in the humanitarian, academic, research and private
label: BODY

text: sectors to engage with us on the peer review process.  Please send feedback on the Framework to
label: BODY

text: centrehumdata@un.org.
label: BODY

text: ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS
label: BODY

text: The initial draft Peer Review Framework was developed by Dani Poole who worked as a Data Fellow with the
label: BODY

text: Centre during the 2019 Data Fellows Programme in June and July The Hague. As part of her research, Dani
label: BODY

text: conducted interviews with over 20 experts including data scientists, researchers, ethicists, and decision makers
label: BODY

text: spanning the humanitarian, academic, and private sectors. The draft Framework was further detailed and
label: BODY

text: refined with input from Leonardo Milano, Evan Tachovsky, Madeline Lisaius, Stuart Campo, Jos Berens, Sarah
label: BODY

text: Telford, Eleonore Fournier-Tombs, Manu Singh, Kirsten Gelsdorf, Nicholas Bodanac, and Fanny Weicherding,
label: BODY

text: among others. We appreciate the time and consideration of the many people who have contributed to this
label: BODY

text: process and will continue to update the Framework on a regular basis.
label: BODY

text: Step 04
label: BODY

text: Step 05
label: BODY

text: Step 06
label: BODY

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data centre.humdata.org  |  Join our mailing list: bit.ly/humdatamailing   |  Twitter: @humdata  |  Email: centrehumdata@un.org
label: BODY

text: ANNEX A
label: HH1

text: ETHICAL REVIEW GUIDE
label: HH1

text: This Ethical Review Guide describes the process for completing the Ethical Matrix. Use the Ethical Matrix
label: BODY

text: template to record your observations as you move through the process.
label: BODY

text: A. List parameters for the development and implementation of the model.
label: BODY

text: What are the parameters limiting the model?
label: BODY

text: List all documents containing parameters for the development and implementation of the model. This may
label: BODY

text: include applicable legal frameworks, organizational procedures, sectoral or organizational codes of ethics and
label: BODY

text: other guidance or governance documents. The Implementation Plan should include a list of key documents for
label: BODY

text: consideration as part of your review.
label: BODY

text: Consider the following types of parameters:
label: BODY

text: •	 Legal, e.g. relevant clauses in applicable data protection legislation. Who would be at risk if the algorithm
label: BODY

text: fails?
label: BODY

text: •	 Contractual, e.g. relevant clauses in contracts applicable to the different stages of the model development
label: BODY

text: and use.
label: BODY

text: •	 Procedural, e.g. relevant sections in applicable data protection and privacy policies.
label: BODY

text: •	 Ethical, e.g. relevant principles and related obligations in (sector-specific) ethical guidance, codes of
label: BODY

text: conduct and similar documents.
label: BODY

text: B. Identify the stakeholders in the context of the model and its intended use.
label: BODY

text: Who is affected by the intended use of the model?
label: BODY

text: The Client will have provided their understanding of relevant stakeholders in the Implementation Plan, but
label: BODY

text: the Ethical Reviewer should consider whether any additional stakeholders should be included in the Ethical
label: BODY

text: Matrix. Stakeholders are actors who could be affected by the use of the model. To identify who is a stakeholder,
label: BODY

text: consider:
label: BODY

text: •	 Who is responsible for implementing the actions based on model output?
label: BODY

text: •	 Who benefits from this model when it works as intended?
label: BODY

text: •	 Who would be at risk if the model fails?
label: BODY

text: •	 Who is directly involved in the development and implementation of the model?
label: BODY

text: Stakeholders may include individuals, groups of individuals (e.g. specific demographics or populations),
label: BODY

text: organizations or specific teams within them (e.g. data team, program delivery team), or government agencies.
label: BODY

text: Insert the identified stakeholders in the ‘Stakeholders’ tab in the Ethical Matrix template, listing them in order
label: BODY

text: of priority. Determine the order of priority based on the centrality of protection, the humanitarian principles
label: BODY

text: and the context of model implementation.
label: BODY

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data centre.humdata.org  |  Join our mailing list: bit.ly/humdatamailing   |  Twitter: @humdata  |  Email: centrehumdata@un.org
label: BODY

text: The below list contains examples of stakeholders that should typically be included. These stakeholders could
label: BODY

text: also be split into subgroups if needed.
label: BODY

text: •	 Affected population
label: BODY

text: •	 Modeller
label: BODY

text: •	 Senior decision-maker
label: BODY

text: •	 Host government
label: BODY

text: •	 Donor
label: BODY

text: •	 Local NGOs / response organizations
label: BODY

text: •	 International NGOs / response organizations
label: BODY

text: •	 Model reviewers
label: BODY

text: C. Identify potential issues.
label: BODY

text: What issues may arise in the implementation of the model?
label: BODY

text: Based on the content in the Model Card, the Model Evaluation Matrix and the Implementation Plan, generate
label: BODY

text: a list of issues that may arise in the implementation of the model. Insert the identified issues in the top row of
label: BODY

text: the Ethical Matrix. Issues should be listed in order of likelihood, placing the issue most likely to occur at the left
label: BODY

text: of the list.
label: BODY

text: A non-comprehensive list of potential issues includes:
label: BODY

text: •	 Inaccuracy. The model’s output is inaccurate. A cyclone impact model estimates that 100,000 people are
label: BODY

text: severely affected by the event but the true number is 180,000 people.
label: BODY

text: •	 Inaction. No action is taken based on the model output. A model predicts a migration of people and no
label: BODY

text: preparations are made in the destination area.
label: BODY

text: •	 Overreaction. A decision informed by the model output leads to action that is too impactful compared
label: BODY

text: to the need that should be addressed. A model predicts a rise in market prices and aid agencies respond by
label: BODY

text: oversupplying the area with foodstuffs, disrupting local markets further.
label: BODY

text: •	 False positive. The model produces a false alarm. A food insecurity model wrongly estimates that a district
label: BODY

text: will face a food security crisis in the next 3 months.
label: BODY

text: •	 False negative. The model misses an event. A food insecurity model does not catch an upcoming food
label: BODY

text: security crisis.
label: BODY

text: •	 Lack of transparency. The algorithms are not made available or are not transparent. The model has been
label: BODY

text: developed by a private company which uses a proprietary software that is not made available.
label: BODY

text: •	 Gaming. Stakeholders can act according to the algorithm’s rules to achieve an intended outcome. An
label: BODY

text: organization systematically inflates the severity of needs of the beneficiaries they are assisting to have
label: BODY

text: greater humanitarian financing.
label: BODY

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data centre.humdata.org  |  Join our mailing list: bit.ly/humdatamailing   |  Twitter: @humdata  |  Email: centrehumdata@un.org 10
label: BODY

text: •	 Statistical bias. The data used to train the algorithm does not reflect the reality on the ground. The
label: BODY

text: displacement data available to train a displacement model only covers 7 out of 10 districts because of
label: BODY

text: limited humanitarian access.
label: BODY

text: •	 Systematic bias. The datasets used to train the algorithm do not reflect the full complexity of the reality.
label: BODY

text: A drought impact model doesn’t take into account factors related to ongoing conflict and insecurity but only
label: BODY

text: environmental factors in a country with ongoing conflict.
label: BODY

text: •	 Corruption. Offering goods/services to make the algorithm present a more favorable outcome. A private
label: BODY

text: company developing an impact model for heat waves is offered compensation from a service provider to
label: BODY

text: tune the parameters of the model to increase the probability of triggering financing.
label: BODY

text: •	 Politics. The outcomes of the model are not acted upon due to competing political interests. A model is
label: BODY

text: developed without an agreed response plan and local actors are not involved in the implementation.
label: BODY

text: •	 Missing attributes. The data used to train and validate the model has missing attributes. The input data
label: BODY

text: for population is not disaggregated by age and the number of children in the affected areas is obtained by
label: BODY

text: extrapolating from the national average.
label: BODY

text: •	 Insufficient data. Historical data on previous impacts is not available for proper testing of the model. An
label: BODY

text: epidemic model is only verified on one historical outbreak.
label: BODY

text: •	 Lack of consent. The model doesn’t align with the consent provided at data collection. The model uses
label: BODY

text: population density data from a private data provider released under a non-disclosure agreement.
label: BODY

text: •	 Privacy infringement.  The model allows individuals or vulnerable groups to be re-identified. A flood
label: BODY

text: impact model uses microdata on displacement population allowing identification of vulnerable groups.
label: BODY

text: •	 Lack of data security. The model’s inputs and outputs are accessed by a non-authorized entity. The
label: BODY

text: model is using sensitive population data that is stored in a non-secured data warehouse.
label: BODY

text: •	 Ossification. The algorithm learns the current state of the world and predicts according to it. Conflict and
label: BODY

text: insecurity escalated in a country where a drought food security model is implemented but the model was
label: BODY

text: tuned on historical data and only considers environmental factors.
label: BODY

text: D. Identify specific ethical concerns of different stakeholders.
label: BODY

text: What ethical concerns do the issues raise for different stakeholders?
label: BODY

text: For each potential issue (columns in the Ethical Matrix), go row-by-row and consider the implications for each
label: BODY

text: stakeholder group. Ask: If this issue occurred (e.g., if the model generated false negatives), would this create an
label: BODY

text: ethical concern for this particular stakeholder group? If yes, how? Record these concerns  in the relevant cell
label: BODY

text: (stakeholder/issue) in the Ethical Matrix template provided.
label: BODY

text: Some stakeholders might need to be split into subgroups if those different subgroups have different concerns.
label: BODY

text: You can add rows to the Ethical Matrix accordingly. Note that not all issues would affect all stakeholders, which
label: BODY

text: should lead to ‘N/A’ in the Matrix.
label: BODY

text: This step is complete when the Ethical Reviewer believes that all relevant stakeholders and concerns are
label: BODY

text: represented in the Matrix.
label: BODY

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data centre.humdata.org  |  Join our mailing list: bit.ly/humdatamailing   |  Twitter: @humdata  |  Email: centrehumdata@un.org 11
label: BODY

text: E. Color-code concerns according to priority level.
label: BODY

text: What’s the priority of a given concern for a specific stakeholder?
label: BODY

text: Review the concerns in the Ethical Matrix one-by-one and assign a priority level.
label: BODY

text: Priority Levels
label: BODY

text: N/A
label: BODY

text: the given issue raises no ethical concerns for this stakeholder.
label: BODY

text: Medium Priority
label: BODY

text: the given issue raises ethical concerns that warrant some attention for this stakeholder.
label: BODY

text: High Priority
label: BODY

text: the given issue raises ethical concerns for this stakeholder that warrant immediate attention
label: BODY

text: and could compromise the use of the model.
label: BODY

text: Judging the level of priority can require a variety of sub-steps, including but not limited to:
label: BODY

text: •	 Considering independently the level of attention the various concerns should receive and the likelihood
label: BODY

text: that the related issue will materialize for the relevant stakeholder.
label: BODY

text: •	 Seeking out complementary information to assess risk, such as probability estimates of model errors (e.g.
label: BODY

text: false negative rate). These estimates will be available to the Ethical Reviewer in the Model Card.
label: BODY

text: •	 Assessing how to rank and weigh the intended use of the algorithm.
label: BODY

text: •	 Using data analysis or other research to validate the priority that the concerns should receive.
label: BODY

text: •	 Deciding how the different issues and related, potentially competing concerns of the different stakeholders
label: BODY

text: will be balanced.
label: BODY

text: •	 Recognizing hard legal and procedural constraints as noted in the Implementation Plan.
label: BODY

text: •	 Considering the potential consequences of using the model versus not using it, i.e. of continuing the
label: BODY

text: process that the algorithm would replace, including the possibility that there is no such process in place.
label: BODY

text: F. Share draft Ethical Matrix with Moderator and participate in client consultation.
label: BODY

text: The Ethical Reviewer should share the draft Ethical Matrix with the Moderator when ready. The Moderator will
label: BODY

text: convene a call with the Client and the Reviewers to present and discuss the initial findings of the review. During
label: BODY

text: this call, the Ethical Reviewer will briefly explain their key observations as reflected in the draft Ethical Matrix.
label: BODY

text: The Client will have the opportunity to provide feedback and to complement the information provided in the
label: BODY

text: Model Card and the Implementation Plan. The Client may also explain if and how any weaknesses in the model
label: BODY

text: have been addressed. If the Client reports that they have taken actions to improve the model, those measures
label: BODY

text: will be reflected in the final versions of the Model Evaluation Matrix and Ethical Matrix.
label: BODY

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data centre.humdata.org  |  Join our mailing list: bit.ly/humdatamailing   |  Twitter: @humdata  |  Email: centrehumdata@un.org 12
label: BODY

text: G. Finalize the Ethical Matrix and develop recommendations to address high-priority concerns.
label: BODY

text: The ultimate goal of the Ethical Review is to have visibility of all concerns and to address all high priority
label: BODY

text: concerns in the model implementation. This means that none of the issues can impact a stakeholder in such a
label: BODY

text: way that it would  impair or cripple the use of the model, or that there is at least an ongoing monitoring system
label: BODY

text: to alert relevant stakeholders of any concerns.
label: BODY

text: If the occurrence of an issue cannot be prevented, recommendations should focus on distributing the impact of
label: BODY

text: the issue equitably so that it only impacts lower priority stakeholders.
label: BODY

text: In this final step, the Ethical Reviewer develops recommendations for each high-priority concern. This typically
label: BODY

text: means developing a recommendation for any concerns in the top left hand 5 x 5 quadrant of the matrix.
label: BODY

text: Recommendations should be included in the final report for the client. Recommendations could include:
label: BODY

text: •	 Updating the model itself (e.g. redefining the objective function, using different training and/or validation
label: BODY

text: data).
label: BODY

text: •	 (Re)defining how the output of the model will be used to inform decisions or resource allocation.
label: BODY

text: •	 Other changes to the programme or service of which the model is part.
label: BODY

text: •	 Experiments, simulations or other research to gauge the impact of design changes on concerns.
label: BODY

text: •	 Developing automated monitoring systems and tools to continuously track the model performance in
label: BODY

text: relation to key concerns.
label: BODY

text: •	 Specifying purposes or settings for which the model can and cannot be used.
label: BODY

text: •	 Explaining the model to users, affected people or other stakeholders.
label: BODY

text: •	 Engaging with stakeholder groups so they can help decide how their concerns will be addressed.
label: BODY

text: The list above makes clear that not all High Priority cells will be ‘resolved’ quickly or finally. For some concerns,
label: BODY

text: the best we can do is create robust monitors and stay vigilant. In any case, new concerns will evolve as
label: BODY

text: community values and constraints change over time. For these reasons, the outcomes of the Ethical Review
label: BODY

text: should serve as a basis for regular revisions of the Ethical Matrix by the client, as the use of the model evolves.
label: BODY
